summary: It's surprising to know that the wild bat which works as a carrier to Ebola virus remains itself immune to the infection. It's well known now that a cholesterol transporter on cell membrane and organelles (NPC1) binds to virus envelope glycoprotein which is an essential step for infection. It's quite possible that virus entry site on NPC1 in wild bats could have gone some adaptive structural change that prevents infection. Studying the structure of NPC1 in wild bats and related genomic study can help designing drugs and vaccines that prevent  Ebola infection.
title: Ebola virus glycoprotein receptor (NPC1) study in carrier wild bats can help to design preventive drugs and vaccines
